The Clean Air Fine Particle Implementation Rule, which was proposed in the Federal Register on 11/12005, included requirements and guidance for State and local air pollution agencies to follow in developing SIP and also the NSR provisions. The final implementation rule that was promulgated on 4/25/2007, included all the SIP related provisions. In this rulemaking, EPA is finalizing the NSR provisions of the 11/1/2005 proposed rule including the major source threshold, significant emissions rate, and offset ratios for PM2.5, interpollutant trading for offsets and applicability of NSR to PM2.5 precursors. This final rule is effective on 7/15/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Control of air pollution by permits for new construction or modification
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Texas SIP, submitted by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) on 10/9/2006. The SIP revision EPA is proposing to approve would require decreased newspaper notice for proposed air quality Standard Permits with statewide applicability to the following metropolitan areas: Austin, Dallas, Houston, and any other regional newspapers the TCEQ Executive Director designates on a case-by-case basis. TCEQ will publish notice of a proposed air quality Standard Permit in the Texas Register and will issue a press release. TCEQ may also use electronic means to inform state and local officials of a proposed air quality Standard Permit. EPA proposes to approve these revisions pursuant to section 110 of the Federal Clean Air Act. Comments must be received on or before 6/16/2008. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, hydrocarbons, intergovernmental relations, lead, NOx, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: General interest - Quick takes: Holly settles Woods Cross refinery pollution charges
Abstract: Holly Refining & Marketing Co settled federal air pollution charges involving its Woods Cros, UT, refinery by agreeing to spend more than $17 million on new and upgraded pollution controls. Holly Corp also agreed to pay a $120,000 civil penalty that EPA and the state of Utah will share. It will also spend on a supplemental environmental project to help fund the purchase of new emergency response equipment for the South Davis Metro Fire Agency. The settlement requires Holly to install pollution controls that will reduce SO2 emissions by 315 ton/yr and NOx by > 105 ton/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern NOx emissions from stationary internal combustion engines. The agency is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. EPA is comments on this proposal and plan to follow with a final action. Any comments must arrive by 6/9/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental relations, NO2, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Agency information collection activities; Proposed collection; Comment request; Rule to reduce interstate transport of fine particulate matter and ozone (Clean air interstate rule) - Final rule; EPA ICR No. 2152.03, OMB Control No. 2060-0570
Abstract: In compliance with the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) (44 U.S.C. 3501 et seq.), this document announces that EPA is planning to submit a request to renew an existing approved Information Collection Request (ICR) to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). This ICR is scheduled to expire on 9/30/2008. Before submitting the ICR to OMB for review and approval, EPA is soliciting comments on specific aspects of the proposed information collection. Comments must be submitted on or before 7/7/2008. Entities potentially affected by this action are units producing electric power which are affected by the Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR). The EPA has promulgated a Rule to Reduce Interstate Transport of Fine Particulate Matter and Ozone (CAIR) that includes new reporting requirements and combines these new requirements with existing requirements from the Consolidated Emissions Reporting Rule (CERR), the Emission Reporting Requirements for Ozone SIP Revisions Relating to Statewide Budgets for NOx Emissions to Reduce Regional Transport of Ozone (NOx SIP Call) and the Acid Rain Program under Title IV of the CAAA. Each of these three existing requirements has an approved ICR in place. The current ICR are: for the CERR, ICR # 0916.10, for the NOx SIP Call, ICR # 1857.03 and for the Acid Rain Program, ICR # 1633.13. This ICR renewal accounts for the incremental burden associated with the CAIR. As such, this supporting statement references the burden analysis included in ICR #s 0916.10, 1857.03, and 1633.13 and estimates the change in burden resulting from the CAIR beyond the scope of these ICR. This ICR renewal is open for public review and comment.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Georgia: Enhanced inspection and maintenance plan
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Georgia SIP, submitted by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, through the Georgia Environmental Protection Division, on 12/28/2007. The revisions include minor changes to Georgia's Air Quality Rules found at Chapter 391-3-20-17, pertaining to rules for Enhanced Inspection and Maintenance (I/M). Enhanced I/M was required for 1-hr ozone nonattainment areas classified as serious and above, under the Clean Air Act. The enhanced I/M program is not a required measure for Atlanta for the 8-hr ozone standard pursuant to the CAA because the area is classified as a moderate nonattainment area (73 FR 12013). However, the enhanced I/M program was approved into the SIP for the 1-hr ozone standard and will remain in the SIP until such time that the State removes the requirement. To remove the requirement from the SIP, the State would have to make a demonstration that removal of this program would not interfere with or delay attainment. To reduce vehicle-related emissions, the I/M program is an approach to ensure that vehicles are maintained properly and verify that the emission control system is operating correctly. This action is being taken pursuant to section 110 of the CAA. This direct final rule is effective on 7/7/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 6/4/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The evolution of carbon capture technology (part 2)
Abstract: The present status of the programs conducted by equipment manufacturers, utilities, research institutions, and government agencies to demonstrate various approaches to carbon capture and sequestration (CCS), is presented. Carbon dioxide capturing approach by Alstrom can be retrofitted onto existing coal plants as it requires considerably less energy than traditional amine processes. Powerspan is pursuing an ammonia-based carbon capture approach that is aimed to be applied to a 125 MW slip stream from a 600 MW unit at NRG Energy's WA Parish plant in Sugar Land, Texas. Siemens and German-based utility E.ON have agreed to cooperate on a new post-combustion solvent approach that is expected to be operational by 2010. Oxy combustion has introduced pure oxygen into the boiler producing a flue gas that is mostly carbon dioxide and water, making it easier to produce a highly pure carbon dioxide stream.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: PACON 2008: Energy and climate change
Abstract: The 21st annual Pacific Congress on Marine Science and Technology Conference (PACON) 2008 will be held in Honolulu, Hawaii, from June 1-5, 2008, under the theme 'Energy and Climate Change- Innovative Approaches to Solving Today's Problems'. The meeting will provide a unique opportunity to marine technologist, engineers, and scientists to network with marine innovators from the rapidly growing Pacific Rim countries. The conference, which also offers a venue for the interchange of new marine development ideas, will further focus on ocean science and technology and coastal science and technology. A special poster session will be organized to encourage students to discuss their work with interested marine professionals in great detail. PACON, which is the only marine science and technology conference allowing meaningful personal interaction, is strongly Asian in its membership and participation, providing a very important niche for Asian powerhouse companies to become acquainted with US governmental and academic counterparts.
Index Keywords: Climate change; Innovation; Technical presentations; climate change; conference proceeding; energy; innovation; science and technology; Hawaii [United States]; Hawaiian Islands; Honolulu; North America; Oahu; Pacific islands; Pacific Ocean; United States

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Alabama prevention of significant deterioration and nonattainment new source review
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve revisions to the Alabama SIP submitted by the State of Alabama on 6/16/2006. The SIP revisions modify Alabama's Prevention of Significant Deterioration regulations in the Alabama SIP to address changes to the federal New Source Review regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002, and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003. EPA proposed approval of these revisions on 1/24/2008; no comments were received on that proposal. The revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plantwide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. This rule will be effective on 6/2/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Indiana; Revisions to particulate matter rules
Abstract: On 3/14/2008, EPA proposed to approve Indiana's 2/21/2008, request to revise its particulate matter SIP for sources in Clark, Dearborn, Dubois, Howard, Lake, Marion, St. Joseph, Vanderburgh, Vigo, and Wayne Counties. This SIP revision updated facility names, revised formatting, removed sources no longer in operation, and revised some emission limits. The State submitted air quality modeling analyses that demonstrated that air quality will continue to be protected in the five counties where some emission limits increased. EPA received one letter containing several comments on the proposal, which called for BP to include limits on sulfur content. Refinery fuel gas contains more sulfur than natural gas, and the sulfur in the fuel will be converted to fine particulate matter in the atmosphere. BP should be required to reduce the sulfur content of its refinery fuel gas in order to meet the proposed PM10 limit. After review of these comments, EPA is approving this SIP revision request. This final rule is effective on 5/30/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for California
Abstract: EPA is finalizing the updates of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations proposed in the Federal Register on 11/16/2007. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of states' seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area (COA), as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the CAAA. The portions of the OCS air regulations that are being updated pertain to the requirements for OCS sources for which the Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District, South Coast Air Quality Management District, and Ventura County Air Pollution Control District are the designated COA. The intended effect of approving the requirements contained in "Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District Requirements Applicable to OCS Sources" (December 2007), "South Coast Air Quality Management District Requirements Applicable to OCS Sources" (Parts I, II, and III) (December 2007), and "Ventura County Air Pollution Control District Requirements Applicable to OCS Sources" (December 2007) is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. This rule is effective on 5/29/2008. The subjects included in 40 CFR Part 55 are presented, which include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, NOx, OCS, ozone, particulate matter, permits, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SOx.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Designation of areas for air quality planning purposes; State of California; PM-10; Revision of designation; Redesignation of the San Joaquin Valley Air Basin PM-10 nonatainment area to attainment; Approval of PM-10 maintenance plan for the San Joaquin Valley Air Basin; Approval of commitments for the East Kern PM-10 nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve the State of California's request to revise the designation for the San Joaquin Valley (SJV) serious nonattainment area for particulate matter of ≤ 10 μ (PM-10) (SJV nonattainment area) by splitting the area into two separate nonattainment areas: The San Joaquin Valley Air Basin serious PM-10 nonattainment area and the East Kern serious PM-10 nonattainment area. EPA is also proposing to redesignate the SJVAB nonattainment area to attainment for the PM-10 NAAQS and proposing to approve the PM-10 maintenance plan, motor vehicle emissions budgets, and conformity trading mechanism for the area. The agency is also proposing to exclude from use in determining that the area has attained the standard two exceedances that EPA has concluded were caused by exceptional events that occurred on 7/4/2007 and 1/4/2008. EPA is proposing to approve enforceable commitments by the Kern County Air Pollution Control District and the CARB to install a PM-10 monitor in the East Kern nonattainment area and to address Clean Air Act requirements under section 189(d) as necessary for the area. Any comments must arrive by 5/27/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Petition for reconsideration and withdrawal of findings of significant contribution and rulemaking for Georgia for purposes of reducing ozone interstate transport
Abstract: EPA is amending a final rule it issued under Section 110 of the Clean Air Act (CAA) related to the transport of NOx. On 4/21/2004, a final rule (Phase II NOx SIP Call Rule) was issued that required the State of Georgia (Georgia) to submit revisions to its SIP to include provisions that prohibit specified amounts of NOx emissions to reduce NOx and ozone transport across State boundaries in the eastern half of US. This rule is effective on 6/21/2004. Subsequently, the Georgia Coalition for Sound Environmental Policy (GCSEP or Petitioners) filed a Petition for Reconsideration requesting that EPA reconsider the applicability of the NOx SIP Call Rule to Georgia. In response to this Petition, and based upon review of additional available information, EPA proposed to remove Georgia from the NOx SIP Call Rule. (6/8/2007). Specifically, EPA proposed to withdraw the applicability of the requirements of the Phase II NOx SIP Call Rule to Georgia, only. Six parties commented on the proposed rule. No requests were made to hold a public hearing. After considering these comments, EPA is issuing a final rule as proposed and this final rule is effective on 58/22/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision to exempt initial fueling of motor vehicles at automobile assembly plants in the St. Louis metropolitan area from the Missouri Performance Evaluation Test Procedures (MO/PETP) approval test requirements. The MO/PETP requirements were initially implemented to maintain the integrity of local air quality by regulating gasoline fueling emissions. Air quality analysis shows that removal of these test requirements for initial fueling at automobile assembly plants will not adversely affect air quality in the St. Louis area. Certain portions of the rule were renumbered and reformatted to ensure consistency between the state and the federally-approved rules. This direct final rule will be effective on 6/2/2008, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 5/2/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revision to the California state implementation plan, Bay Area Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA finalizes the approval of revisions to the Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) portion of the California SIP. These revisions, which were proposed in the Federal Register on 12/20/2007, concern NOx and CO emissions from boilers, steam generators, and process heaters at petroleum refineries. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. This rule is effective on 5/2/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor: Concerns raised over growth of China's CO2 emissions
Abstract: According to a new analysis conducted at the University of California, Berkeley, and UC San Diego, the growth in China's CO2 emissions is far outpacing previous estimates, making the goal of stabilizing atmospheric greenhouse gases even more difficult. Previous estimates shows that the region that includes China will see a 2.5-5% annual increase in CO2 emissions between 2004 and 2010. The new UC analysis pegs China's annual growth rate at 11%, at a minimum, for the same time period. The researcher predicted that by 2010, there will be an increase of 600 million ton of CO2 emissions in China over the country's levels in 2000. This growth from China alone would dramatically overshadow the 116 million ton of carbon emissions reductions pledged by all the developed countries in the Kyoto Protocol and surpassed those of the US in 2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: A new approach to material transport
Abstract: Jamalco/Alcoa awarded a contract to Doppelmayr Transport Technology GmbH in September, 2007, to install its biggest material transportation system, RopeCon® at the Mt. Olyphant Mine. The Olyphant RopeCon® system integrates the world's largest flat belt with corrugated side walls, with a total length of 3.4 km and a vertical descent of 470 m. Doppelmayr Transport Technology GmbH states that the system represents an optimum solution, which will be able to meet Jamalco/Alcoa's requirements, including environmental sustainability and satisfying its client's needs and expectations. The new system will generate significant braking energy per hour, minimize space requirements, save 1,200 truck journeys a day, and reducing carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions.
Index Keywords: Belt conveyors; Braking; Carbon dioxide; Customer satisfaction; Optimization; Corrugated side walls; Doppelmayr Transport Technology GmbH (CO); Material transportation system; Materials handling equipment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: What state emits the most carbon
Abstract: According to 2/28/2008 report in Newsweek, Texas produces more carbon emissions than most countries. In terms of carbon emissions, it would rank just behind Canada at no. 8 in the world for the highest carbon emissions. The state managed to reduce its emissions by about 40 million ton since 2003 when it was ranked the Earth's seventh largest CO2 emitter. Texas is the leading producer of energy and has more cattle and oil refineries than any other state. Raising cattle contributes quite a bit to the production of carbon through the release of methane and CO2 from transportation and processing operations. One in four vehicles registered in Texas is a pickup truck. That compares with 16% for the rest of the registered vehicles in the US.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State rules: Colorado - Roadside emissions testing begins
Abstract: Colorado's Department of Public Health and Environment has begun an implementation phase at identifying high-polluting and low-polluting vehicles using roadside testing equipment. Under the program, identified clean-operating vehicles are exempt from standard on-site emissions inspection.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: United Kingdom: Carbon Trust issues pyrolysis challenge
Abstract: The Carbon Trust, a government-funded company helping businesses and the public sector to cut carbon emissions, is calling for expressions of interest from potential partners within the scientific community to collaborate in the development of a world-class commercially-viable pyrolysis oil upgrading process. The trust is seeking to invest in one or more commercially-focused research projects in this area over the next 3-5 yr. Pyrolysis oil from sustainable biomass could potentially be a valuable source of affordable, environmentally-friendly fuels, provided they can be integrated into a conventional refinery. The funded research should lead to proof of principle for a novel process for low-cost and low greenhouse gas (GHG) intensity upgrading of biomass pyrolysis oil; characterization of the upgraded oil, assessment of the likely commercial and environmental value of any associated co-products and processes for their exploitation; development of a demonstration unit; and modeling of the full-scale process economics, whole system GHG intensity and key technical parameters.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News industry: European energy management standard
Abstract: To meet UK government's target of a 60% emissions cut by 2050, a new European standard on energy management is being developed, which sets out the requirements for a system which will allow all organizations to continually improve their energy efficiency and to be independently certified to this effect. BSI British Standards is inviting comments on the draft of this standard, the deadline for comments is 5/31/2008. EN 16001 uses the well-established "plan-do-check-act" model for establishing an energy management system. Organization of any size or type can develop and implement a policy and objectives which incorporate legal and other requirements such as emissions trading obligations and agreements with community groups. EN 16001 aims to help businesses shrink their carbon footprint, through energy efficiency, as well as reduce costs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Rhode Island; Diesel anti-idling regulation
Abstract: The EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted on 11/29/2007 by the State of Rhode Island. This SIP revision includes a regulation that prohibits the unnecessary idling of diesel engines and vehicles in Rhode Island. The regulation sets limits for the amount of time and under what conditions diesel engines may idle. The regulation will result in emission reductions of VOC, NOx, CO, and fine particulate matter. EPA is approving the rule because the standards and requirements set by the rule will strengthen the Rhode Island SIP. The intended effect of this action is to approve this rule into the Rhode Island SIP. EPA is approving this rule pursuant to the Clean Air Act. This direct final rule will be effective on 5/27/2008, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 4/28/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Partial removal of direct final rule revising the California State Implementation Plan, Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District and San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: On 1/2/2008 (73 FR 48), EPA published a direct final approval of revisions to the California SIP. These revisions concerned local rules that address circumvention, reduction of animal matter, and VOC emissions from gasoline bulk storage tanks, gasoline filling stations, petroleum refinery equipment, and petroleum solvent dry cleaning. The direct final action was published without prior proposal because EPA anticipated no adverse comment. The direct final rule stated that if adverse comments were received by 2/1/2008, EPA would publish a timely removal in the Federal Register. The agency received a timely adverse comment. Consequently, with this revision EPA is removing the direct final approval of SJVAPCD Rules 4104, 4402, 4404, 4453, 4454, 4625, 4641, and 4672. The other rules, MBUAPCD Rules 415, 418, and 1002, approved in the 1/2/2008 direct final action, are not affected by this removal and are incorporated into the SIP as of the original effective date of 3/3/2008. The addition of 40 CFR 52.220(c)(351)(i)(C) published at 73 FR 48 on (1/2/2008) is removed effective 3/13/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy Policy Act of 2005 Diesel Emissions Reduction Program; State clean diesel grant program funding fiscal year 2008
Abstract: The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (H.R. 6) signed into law on 8/8/2005 incorporates provisions to achieve significant reductions in diesel emissions. Section 793 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 authorizes the EPA to support grant and loan programs administered by States that are designed to achieve significant reductions in diesel emissions. This program authorized in Section 793 is referred to as the State Clean Diesel Grant Program for this Notice. EPA expects to have ≈ $14.8 million available in fiscal year 2008 in the form of assistance agreements to issue under the State Clean Diesel Grant Program. To participate, States must notify EPA of their intent to apply to the State Clean Diesel Grant Program through a Notice of Intent to Apply on or before 4/24/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Motor vehicle emissions budgets; State of New Jersey
Abstract: The EPA is proposing to approve a SIP revision submitted by the State of New Jersey. This revision updates the direct PM2.5 and NOx motor vehicle emissions budgets for Mercer County, located within the New Jersey portion of the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, NY-NJ-CT, PM2.5 nonattainment area. The intended effect of this rulemaking is to approve budgets that will be used to determine transportation conformity. Comments must be received on or before 4/4/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Climate change: Canadian cities are doing their share
Abstract: Climate change is occurring and municipalities are strategically positioned to adopt adaptive measures and to initiate environmentally sustainable practices. 'Anticipatory adaptation' rather than 'reactive adaptation, is suggested as being the most cost-effective and efficient plan of action. Cities have a large role to play in developing and implementing policies that address climate change and its impact, and their success in this area will have a direct impact on citizens' quality of life.
Index Keywords: adaptive management; climate change; environmental planning; environmental policy; urban planning; Canada; North America

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Adipic acid unit at Shenma Company achieved apparent effect in energy consumption and emissions reduction
Source title: China Petroleum Processing and Petrochemical Technology
Abstract: The nitrous oxide disposal unit, in which Shenma Nylon Chemicals Co in Henan province has invested, was pre-commissioned in November 2007 to realize the detoxification of all gases generated by the adipic acid unit. The project independently can reduce the emission of about 16.8 kton of nitrous oxide from the firm. Shenma Nylon Chemicals Co consumes 65 thousand ton/yr of coke for hydrogen production that is used by the pure benzene unit and cyclohexanol unit.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: One big green machine
Abstract: RR Donnelley produces printing using Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) chain-of-custody certified papers to respond to the needs of its plants in Mexico, Canada, the US, and China. The company is also pursuing sustainability initiatives and for efficient operations across its platform and across the world. The company became the first printer to use water washers to reduce the emissions associated with letterpress printing. RR Donnelley received the Environmental Stewardship Award from Orion Energy Systems for implementing projects that can displace 437 million kilowatt hours of electricity consumed over the lifetime. The company has completed lighting system retrofits in more than two dozen of its domestic and international facilities. RR Donnelley has also invested in the latest oxidizers to control emissions and reduce natural gas usage, while achieving better overall performance.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Gas extraction promises safety, economic pluses
Abstract: Swiss scientists are working at Lake Kivu, between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, to recover methane in order to prevent its accidental release and to ensure power supplies. Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology (Eawag) scientists, Dubendorf, Switzerland, have found that the methane gas concentration has increased significantly in the lake region. The change is attributed mainly to increased nutrient inputs from the growing population and to the introduction of sardine species. The rising gas concentration was found to be a risk factor as accidental lake disruption by an earthquake or a landslide could lead to massive eruption. A series of Workshops, involving international experts, were organized to discuss the best way of dealing with the problem. A continuous monitoring program and a computer simulation was also developed for lake studies.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The evolution of carbon capture technology part 1
Abstract: Several of the power sector original equipment manufacturers are working closely with electric utilities, government and industry research institutions to capture carbon produced by coal-fired power plants. Powerspan is pursuing an ammonia based carbon capture approach to separate CO2 from natural gas and other gases that does not chill ammonia. The company's ECO2 post-combustion regenerative process, which evolved from its ammonia-based multi-pollutant capture approach, is planned to be applied to a 125 MW slip stream from a 600 MW unit at NRG's W.A. Parish plant in Sugar Land, Texas. Siemens and German-based utility E.ON have agreed to cooperate on a new post-combustion solvent approach that is claimed to be both environmentally harmless and biodegradable and results in zero emissions. A pilot installation at an E.ON power plant in Germany is expected to be in operation by the year 2010.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government: Taiwan vehicles start shift to E3 fuel
Abstract: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen activated a "green government vehicle" program by ordering that all vehicles owned by the central government and the Taipei municipal government use E3. Since every 1000 L of E3 can contribute to a reduction of 2.1 ton of CO2 emissions, the green program - the first stage of a comprehensive plan to promote the consumption of biofuels nationwide - can help slow global warming. Under the Energy Bureau's plan, by 2009, all service stations in the country's two main cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung will sell E3, with $61.9 million/yr for local farmers.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer Continental Shelf air regulations consistency update for Massachusetts
Abstract: EPA is proposing to update a portion of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of States' seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area, as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the Clean Air Act. The portion of the OCS air regulations that is being updated pertains to the requirements for OCS sources in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 55 includes environmental protection, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx. Written comments must be received on or before 3/28/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Indiana; VOC emissions from fuel grade ethanol production operations
Abstract: EPA is approving a 3/30/2007, request from the Indiana Department of Environmental Management to revise the Indiana SIP by adding a VOC rule for fuel grade ethanol production at dry mills as amendments to 326 IAC 8-5. This rule revision creates an industry-specific BACT standard for new fuel grade ethanol production dry mills that replaces the otherwise required case-by-case SIP BACT determination for new facilities with the potential to emit ≥ 25 ton/yr of VOC. The state of Indiana believes that this rule will increase the clarity, predictability, and timeliness of its air permits for this particular group of sources. These rules were proposed for approval on 9/13/2007, and comments were received on 10/8/2007. This final rule is effective on 3/21/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor: FutureGen picks Mattoon, Ill.
Abstract: In mid-December 2007, members of the FutureGen for Illinois taskforce, elected officials, local residents, and Governor Rod R. Blagojevich (D) celebrated the FutureGen Industrial Alliance's decision to construct the first near-zero-emissions coal-fired power plant in their state. FutureGen will take the form of a near-zero-emissions, integrated gasification combined-cycle power plant that will capture 90% of its CO2 emissions and sequester them in geological formations > 1 mi underground. The Mt. Simon Sandstone is a saline reservoir underlying most of the Illinois Basin that has served as a natural gas reservoir, and scientists expect it will work well to store CO2 as well. The possibility of on-site injection at Mattoon was likely a key factor in its selection. The on-site sequestration would both simplify operations and help with public education because visitors to FutureGen could just "step out the back door of the plant" to see where its CO2 is going.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Massachusetts; Certification of Tunnel Ventilation Systems in the Metropolitan Boston Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Massachusetts, which consists of technical revisions to Massachusetts regulation 310 CMR 7.38, "Certification of Tunnel Ventilation Systems in the Metropolitan Boston Air Pollution Control District." The amendments better define the emissions monitoring techniques for various types of tunnel ventilation systems, and provide flexibility in emission monitoring requirements. This action is being taken in accordance with the Clean Air Act. This direct final rule will be effective on 4/15/2008, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 3/17/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Regulation No. 7, Section XII, Volatile organic compounds from oil and gas operations
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a SIP revision submitted by the State of Colorado. On 8/3/2007, the Governor's designee submitted revisions to Colorado's Regulation No. 7, Emissions of Volatile Organic Compounds, Section XII, VOC From Oil and Gas Operations. EPA is approving the revisions to Regulation No. 7, Section XII. This action is being taken under Section 110 of the Clean Air Act. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC. This direct final rule is effective on 4/14/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 3/14/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio; Oxides of nitrogen budget trading program
Abstract: EPA is granting final approval to Ohio's request for the retirement and withdrawal of 240 NOx allowances from the State's 2005 new source set aside. Retiring 240 new source set aside allowances will provide surplus emission reductions to help compensate for the discontinuation of Ohio's motor vehicle inspection and maintenance program (known as ECheck) in the Cincinnati and Dayton areas for the year 2006. EPA received adverse comments and one positive comment on the proposed rulemaking on the allowance retirement. These comments are addressed in this notice. As a result of this action, 240 NOx allowances from the State's 2005 new source set aside will be withheld and permanently retired. This final rule is effective on 3/14/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NOx, NOx budget trading program.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and Promulgation of Air Quality Implementation Plans; Texas; Texas Low-Emission Diesel Fuel Program
Abstract: EPA proposes the approval of a revision to the SIP for the state of Texas. This revision makes changes to the Texas Low-Emission Diesel (TXLED) Fuel program. The revision establishes a replicable procedure for the State to approve Alternative Emission Reduction Plans, extends the date of state approvals, and brings marine diesel fuels under the TXLED program. The revision also refines and clarifies testing requirements. The changes being proposed for approval positively influence the reductions of NOx to be achieved. Comments must be received on or before 3/13/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans and operating permits program; State of Kansas
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Kansas SIP for the purpose of revoking the Sulfur Compound Emissions rule and for the purpose of approving revisions to the Class I major source operating permit annual emissions inventory rule and several Class II minor source operating permits rules. The rule, which is related to emissions of sulfur compounds, and was originally adopted in 1972, established limitations for SOx emissions from primary nonferrous, i.e., lead and zinc, smelters, and prohibited emission or combustion of process gas streams, such as those found at petroleum refineries containing H2S above the specified limits. EPA is also approving an additional submittal by the State of Kansas pertaining to amendments of the Class II operating permit rules, which were amended by the Kansas Department of Health and Environment on 2/20/98, but had not previously been submitted for EPA approval. In addition, EPA is approving a revision to the Class II operating permit rules adopted in 2005. The Class II operating permit rules were primarily revised to align the annual emission inventory reporting date deadline with the 6/1/2008 payment of Annual Emissions Fee rule. EPA approval will ensure consistency between the state and the Federally-approved rules. This direct final rule will be effective on 4/8/2008, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 3/10/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proposed Settlement Agreement, Clean Air Act Citizen Suit
Abstract: In accordance with section 113(g) of the Clean Air Act, as amended, 42 U.S.C. 7413(g), notice is hereby given of a proposed settlement agreement, to address a lawsuit filed by the Battery Council International (BCI) in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit: Battery Council International vs. EPA, No. 07-1364 (D.C. Cir.). On 9/13/2007, BCI filed a petition for review challenging regulations promulgated by EPA in a final rule entitled "National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Area Sources: Acrylic and Modacrylic Fibers Production, Carbon Black Production, Chemical Manufacturing: Chromium Compounds, Flexible Polyurethane Foam Production and Fabrication, Lead Acid Battery Manufacturing, and Wood Preserving" published at 72 FR 38864 (7/16/2007). Written comments on the proposed settlement agreement must be received by 3/10/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Final rule; Ohio; Revised oxides of nitrogen (NOx) regulation, phase II, and revised NOx trading rule
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Ohio NOx SIP containing provisions, which control NOx emissions from large internal combustion (IC) engines, makes corrections to typographical errors in the previously approved Phase I NOx SIP, and expands the definition of NOx budget unit. This approval requires NOx emissions reductions from large IC engines, based on cost-effective control measures. Large IC engines are defined in the State rule as emitting ≥ 1 ton/day of NOx during the ozone season. The Ohio NOx SIP Call IC engine inventory is based on the inventory of IC engines compiled by EPA as part of the NOx SIP Call rule. Including these engines in the Ohio plan reduces NOx to a level at which the State will meet its ozone season NOx budget. EPA is approving the State's revision because it satisfies the Federal requirements for Phase II sources and shows that these rules will meet the Phase II budget for Ohio. This direct final rule is effective on 4/4//2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 3/5/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Hedge your bets
Abstract: The European Commission explained how it proposes to achieve EU targets for cutting greenhousegas (GHG) emissions and increasing the share of renewables in the energy mix. The targets, approved in March 2007 by member states, are for a 20% cut in GHG emissions from the 1990 baseline, increasing to 30% if countries outside the EU agree to emissions caps, and for renewables to be supplying 20% of the EU's energy by the same deadline. No single energy technology will be capable of achieving the very large cuts required. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, GHG emissions will have to be reduced by 50-80% by 2050. A range of solutions will be needed, including efficiency improvements in transportation and energy production, wider deployment of renewables, the application of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology to coal-fired power generation, and growth in the biofuels and nuclear sectors. The UK's new energy bill deserves recognition for its efforts to promote offshore wind farms, a form of energy that has great potential in the UK, and other technologies such as CCS.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: Western Europe: Norway: The ministry of petroleum and energy...
Abstract: Norway's ministry of petroleum and energy has agreed to delay plans for a carbon capture and storage (CCS) facility at the gas-fired combined-heat-and-power station being built by StatoilHydro at its Mongstad refinery. An investment decision on the CO2 test center at Mongstad, due to be taken by StatoilHydro, Dong Energy, Gassnova, Shell, and Vattenfall in the first quarter of 2008, has been put back to the last quarter. Consequently, the test facility will not be operating until 2011, after the start-up of the power station, although the State Pollution Control Authority had said CCS must be in place at start-up. The government will buy emissions certificates for 100,000 ton/yr of CO2 until the full-scale CCS facility is built, in 2014 at the earliest.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: SECAs not lowering marine fuel sulphur content
Abstract: According to DNVPS managing director Tore Morten Wetterhus, sulfur levels in marine fuel supplied in the North Sea had declined by about 0.2% after this area became a SECA in August 2008. The company's findings showed regions such as the Middle East and the US Gulf Coast registering an increased amount of sulfur in their supplied bunkers, prompting suggestions that the two SECA had merely redistributed the sulfur content to less regulated areas. Wetterhus further urged shipping companies to make a concerted and thorough effort to reduce CO2 emission before more regulations are forced upon them. According to Wetterhus, environmental regulations whether directed at SOx, NOx, or CO2 must be cost-effective to comply with, and applied globally to get the necessary buy-in from all players in the industry.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: CARB moves on cold ironing
Abstract: Mary Nichols, Chairman of the CARB has highlighted two port-related emissions reductions programs that will significantly reduce diesel particulate matter pollution from ships and trucks throughout the state by 2014. The first requires operators of certain types of ocean-going vessels to shut down their diesel auxiliary machinery while docked at the state's busiest ports in favor of using shore-based electrical power. The second is aimed at cleaning up emissions from the aging fleet of diesel trucks that hauls good to and from ports and rail yards throughout the state. Combined with these new measures, CARB regulations will reduce diesel particulate matter emissions form container and cruise ship terminals by almost two-thirds by 2010, and by an estimated 75% by 2014. Overall, diesel soot emissions will decrease by 1800 ton/yr in 2014.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World news: Shell: Reducing emissions
Abstract: As part of the ongoing cooperation between Audi and Shell, global leaders from the worlds of politics, economics, and non-profit organizations at the World Economic Forum in Davos will be chauffeured to the event in Audi TDI cars fuelled by Shell gas to liquids fuel. The mixture of the synthetic diesel type fuel and the latest diesel technology can significantly contribute to cleaner tailpipe emissions. With > 5% of the world's population living in urban areas, there is evidence that local vehicle exhaust emissions are a major challenge to air quality. Synthetic fuels have been shown to contribute to improved air quality in major cities and have immediate impacts on emissions across public vehicle fleets.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Marine fuels and emissions: IBIA advises changes to EU distillate sulphur limits
Abstract: According to the International Bunker Industry Association (IBIA), for the period from 8/11/2006 to 12/31/2007, the 0.2% sulfur limit on distillate fuel consumed by ships applies only to marine gas oils used in EU territory with a viscosity or density falling within the ranges defined for DMX and DMA grades under ISO 8217. The exemption for Greece and the outermost regions continues to apply. DMX is a special light distillate intended mainly for use in emergency engines, while DMA (also called MGO) is a general-purpose marine distillate that must be free from traces of residual fuel. The IBIA notes that for DMB (marine diesel oil) and DMC (which may contain significant amounts of residual fuel), the 0.2% sulfur limit in EU territory is dropped, and a less stringent 1.5% sulfur cap is introduced for fuels placed on the market in EU member states' territories. This is to allow the use of marine diesel oils to comply with the requirements in SOx emission control areas, in case supplies of 1.5% heavy fuel oil are insufficient. The end date of 12/31/2007 did not apply to the dropping of the 0.2% sulfur limit for DMB and DMC. For DMA and DMX, from 1/1/2008 to 12/31/2009, a 0.1% sulfur limit applies to marine gas oils used in EU territory with a viscosity or density falling within the ranges defined for DMX and DMA grades under ISO 8217.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Chipping away at emissions
Abstract: The government of Quebec, Canada, has asked the mechanical contracting firm, R. Nantel & Associès Inc., Montreal, to survey its northern hospitals, determining their requirement for biomass boilers. The government has asked the company to conduct the survey of its northern hospitals, in an effort to comply with the environmental regulations and reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. The government wants its northern hospitals, to use biomass boilers, as they utilize wood waste from local mills and significantly improve energy efficiency of the hospitals, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The latest biomass boilers are also equipped with better emissions control devices that significantly reduce NOx and CO emissions.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Boilers; Contracts; Energy efficiency; Environmental regulations; Greenhouse gases; Biomass boilers; Emissions control devices; Mechanical contracting; Mechanical engineering

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Turbocharger updates bring benefits for engines old and new
Abstract: Turbocharger upgrades are providing significant benefits for both old and low-emission engines. It has been found that retrofitting new turbochargers to old engines provide significant benefits, while the latest generation of low-emission engines rely on high pressure turbocharging, to comply with low emission regulations. MAN Diesel, one of the major designers and manufacturers of turbochargers for large engines, states that retrofitting an engine, with its latest turbochargers can make it feasible and prove cost-effective and helpful in extending the life of the engine. These turbochargers can also improve fuel consumption, performance, and environmental impact. The company also states that turbocharger retrofits address a wide range of issues that can be resolved by the application of a new and high efficiency turbocharger.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: StateRules: Delaware - Tradeoff triggers more permits
Abstract: In 2006, the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control reached an agreement with the Premcor Refining Group that would significantly reduce NOx emissions from their Delaware City facility. The agreement resolved ongoing new source review violations at the facility and required NOx emissions from the FCC unit to be erduced to 20 ppm by 5/1/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: StateRules: California - States join California
Abstract: In August 2005, the Golden State adopted regulations establishing greenhouse gas emissions limits for vehicles solid in the state starting 2009. The EPA has held the California waiver request for 2 yr and has yet to make a decision, which prompted the lawsuit. The suit claims the EPA "unlawfully withheld and unreasonably delayed" action on its waiver request. According to the suit, the EPA's inaction is also preventing those regulations from being implemented in 15 other states.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: United Kingdom: Biofuels under fire
Abstract: The EU is coming under pressure to modify its policy for ensuring that Europe's cars run partially on biofuels. According to a report by the UK's Environmental Audit Committee, biofuels are ineffective at cutting greenhouse gases and called on the EU to abandon its biofuels target, which the Committee says is doing more harm than good. This echoes the view of the Royal Society (RS), which warned the UK government that the Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation (RTFO), the UK?s implementation of the European policy, would do more to help the economy and guarantee energy security than to cut emissions and reduce climate change. According to RS' report (Sustainable biofuels: prospects and challenges), the RTFO requires 5% of all UK transport fuels to come from renewable sources by 2010, yet it fails to stipulate emission reduction targets. Biofuels are not a silver bullet for global warming or emission reductions and that any forward-looking strategy should include improved engine and vehicle design, and increased use of public transport in association with better town-planning.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Michigan; Oxides of nitrogen regulations, phase II
Abstract: EPA is approving Michigan's NOx rules that satisfy the requirements of EPA's NOx SIP Call Phase II Rule. The agency is approving these regulations based on Michigan's demonstration that they will result in the achievement of the Phase II budget through source compliance with rules affecting stationary internal combustion (IC) engines which are identified in the NOx plan submittal. Limiting NOx emissions from IC engines will allow the State to meet the Phase II incremental difference of 1033 ton during the ozone season, thereby improving air quality and protecting the health of Michigan citizens. This direct final will be effective on 3/31/2008, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 2/28/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maine; Ozone maintenance plans
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Maine, that includes four separate 8-hr ozone maintenance plans. The Clean Air Act requires that areas that are designated attainment for the 8-hr ozone standard, and also had been previously designated either nonattainment or maintenance for the 1-hr ozone standard, develop a plan showing how the state will maintain the ozone standard for the area. Maine's maintenance plans include an emissions inventory, a plan for how the state will demonstrate and track progress of continued maintenance of the standard, a commitment to continue ozone monitoring, and a contingency plan that will ensure that any violation of the 8-hr ozone standard is promptly addressed. The intended effect of this action is to approve these four maintenance plans into the Maine SIP. This action is being taken under the Clean Air Act. This direct final rule will be effective on 3/31/2008, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 2/28/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and Promulgation of Implementation Plans; Alabama Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve SIP revisions submitted by the State of Alabama on 6/16/2006. The proposed revisions modify Alabama's Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review regulations in the SIP to address changes to the federal New Source Review permitting Regulations. The proposed revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plantwide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. The list of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 includes environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, NO2 ozone, and particulate matter. Comments must be received on or before 2/25/2008.

Authors: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.3, Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate, Division on Earth and Life Studies, National Research Council
Title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.3: Reanalyses of historical climate data for key atmospheric features: Implications for attribution of causes of observed change
Source title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.3: Reanalyses of Historical Climate Data for Key Atmospheric Features: Implications for Attribution of Causes of Observed Change
Authors with affiliations: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.3; Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate; Division on Earth and Life Studies; National Research Council
Abstract: The U.S. Climate Change Science Program is in the process of producing 21 draft assessments that investigate changes in the Earth's climate and related systems. These assessments are designed to inform decisionmakers about the scientific underpinnings of a range of environmental issues, such as models of past climate conditions. This National Research Council book reviews one of these assessments, Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.3 "Reanalyses of Historical Climate Data for Key Atmospheric Features: Implications for Attribution of Causes of Observed Change." The committee commends the authors for clearly stating their goals and their intended audience and for their fidelity in following the prospectus. However, the current draft needs revision to better link reanalysis and attribution. In addition, the document needs to better explain how reanalysis fits into climate science and include a general description of how climate science is done and how the models, observations, and theories are related to the ultimate goal of reanalysis, especially for the benefit of non-specialists. © 2008 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State implementation plan, San Joaquin valley air pollution control district and Sacramento Metropolitan air quality management district
Abstract: In this direct final rule, EPA approves revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District and Sacramento Metropolitan Air Quality Management District portions of the California SIP. These revisions concern NOx emissions from internal combustion engines and stationary gas turbines. EPA is approving local rules to regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 3/10/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 2/11/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District and San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District (MBUAPCD) and San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District (SJVAPCD) portions of the California SIP. Under authority of the CAAA, EPA is approving local rules that address circumvention, reduction of animal matter, and VOC emissions from gasoline bulk storage tanks, gasoline filling stations, petroleum refinery equipment, and petroleum solvent dry cleaning. This rule is effective on 3/3/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 2/1/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: ExxonMobil is investing $100m to construct...
Abstract: ExxonMobil is investing $100 million to construct a plant near LaBarge, WY, for the commercial demonstration of Controlled Freeze Zone gas-treating technology. The process, which involves freezing and then melting the CO2 and removing other components including H2S from sour gas, could make carbon capture and storage more affordable and significantly reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. The plant will process about 14 million cu ft/day.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: Canada: The Canadian and Saskatchewan...
Abstract: The Canadian and Saskatchewan governments are jointly developing a $(Can)480 million commercial demonstration of carbon capture and storage to sequester CO2 from coal-fired power plants. The captured CO2 would be used for EOR in a province where EnCana and Apache are already operating two projects, producing a combined 16,000 bpd.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: Biofuels expansion vs low-carbon approach
Abstract: Quantity targets for adding biofuels into the EU's energy mix should be scrapped in favor of a low-carbon policy approach. According to Jos Dings, director of the European Federation for Transport and Environment, biofuel producers were confused about whether to invest in "cheap or clean biofuels" because member state governments have changed their biofuel targets, creating uncertainty in the market. Dings said under a low-carbon approach, which is being developed in California, companies would invest in low-carbon methods at the cheapest cost. The European Commission has proposed that it will review the fuel quality directive to see if it can use this method instead.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Case 9 - The harmless substance
Source title: Environmental Liability and Ecological Damage in European Law
Abstract: A's industrial plant releases a chemical substance into the environment that is generally considered to be harmless to human health. Recent medical studies, however, show that this substance can cause a very specific form of asthma. B, who suffers from this asthma, wants to sue A for damages. A objects that he did not know, and could not have known, that the emissions of his plant can cause this disease. Is A liable? Comparative remarks Comparison The capability to foresee the risk of an activity is an essential prerequisite for a fault-based liability. Thus, in most European countries, fault cannot be established, if the operator of a plant did not and, due to the lack of empirical and scientific knowledge, could not have known that emissions from its plant were capable of causing damage. Only the Portuguese reporter stated that such circumstances do not exclude fault liability according to Article 22 LAP. Under theories of strict liability, most jurisdictions do not allow the defendant to escape liability by showing that he did not and could not have known the risk. Product liability, however, poses an exception to this rule, as Article 7(e) of the EC Products Liability Directive provides that the producer of a defective product shall not be liable if he proves ‘that the state of scientific and technical knowledge at the time when he put the product into circulation was not such as to enable the existence of the defect to be discovered’. © Cambridge University Press 2008 and 2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: Canada: the British Columbia government has legislated...
Abstract: The British Columbia government has legislated for a 33% reduction in 2007 greenhouse-gas (GHG) emissions levels by 2020 and 80% by 2050, making it the first of Canada's 10 provinces to enshrine GHG cuts. It also requires distributors of gasoline and diesel to reduce the CO2 content of those fuels by 10% by 2020. Large industries will be able to participate in emissions-trading systems.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environmental issues dominate POWER-GEN international
Abstract: POWER GEN International 2007 conference, held in New Orleans, US, between 11-13 December, 2007, focused on developing cost-effective solutions aimed at capturing and sequestering CO2, to comply with potential CO 2 regulations. Some of the speakers at the event requests the participants, to help in developing CO2 regulations and help in reducing and monitoring CO2 emissions. One of the speakers at the event suggested that all the states in the US need to work together, to develop a comprehensive CO2 emissions regulation and comply with it. Another speaker presented detailed statistics about the effects of greenhouse gases and discussed the events and issues that are expected to increase the effect of greenhouse gases.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: MAN recirculation cuts emissions
Abstract: MAN Diesel is developing practical steps to produce emissions reduction technology, as exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) has achieved up to 70% reductions in NOx emissions. The EGR method is based on a reduction of the oxygen content in the cylinder charge and the recirculation of exhaust gas on the engine side of the turbocharger. During the process, an electrical, high-pressure blower drives the exhaust gas through a wet scrubber to a higher-pressure scavenge-air receiver. The scrubber cleans the exhaust gas by removing SOx and particulates, and cools it through humidification, before reintroduction to the combustion chamber. The NOx limiting effect is obtained by reducing the local maximum combustion temperatures in the combustion chamber, and reducing the concentration of oxygen by the addition of inert media with high specific heat, either exhaust gas or water vapor.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Catalyst overview: Grace Davison
Abstract: Grace Davison refining technologies develop and manufacture FCC catalysts and additives that enable refiners to increase profits by improving yields and product quality. The company offers FCC catalysts for maximization of propylene, and ZSM-5 zeolite additives for maximizing propylene and gasoline octane, and additives promoting co-combustion in the regenerator. The current portfolio of additives allows refiners to reduce SOx and NOx emissions from their FCC units and lowering sulfur content in gasoline and diesel fuel. ART, a joint venture in 2001 combining the technology of Grace Davison and Chevron to develop premium state of the art hydroprocessing catalysts, has hydrotreating product line that includes StART (Silicon tolerance by ART) for naphtha hydrotreating units professing cracked naphtha feedstock, SmART (sulfur minimization by ART) for the production of ultra low sulfur diesel, and ApART (Advanced pretreat by ART).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: PrimeServ makes it four out of four for ATC
Abstract: The after-sales arm of the MAN Diesel Group, MAN Diesel PrimeServ, has made a contract under its Engine Management Concept (EMC) for marine engines aboard a shuttle tanker that is operated by the Alaska Tanker Company (ATC). The contract with the ship management and marine transportation specialists gives PrimeServ delegated engine responsibility of maintenance for all four shuttle tankers in the ATC fleet. The contract include all spare parts to be delivered for scheduled maintenance and supervision by PrimeServ technicians during major overhauls at 6,000 hour intervals that include turbocharger overhauls. The contract states that PrimeServ offers help on technical and operational matters, and has the provision that online service via remote data transfer will be implemented with the availability of an economical, high capacity telecommunications link. MAN Diesel PrimeServ is also helping ATC to study emission-reduction methods intensively for the shuttle tanker engines.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The third OPEC summit: A report from the field
Abstract: The Third OPEC Summit was called for the three official themes, which were providing petroleum, promoting prosperity, and protecting the planet, and the three official themes also discussed the high prices of the oil. The two day Summit, held in Riyadh, was followed by a two day Ministerial discussions and assured not to make any of the usual supply decisions. Saudi Oil Minister Ali Al-Naimi stated that the prices are not associated to the fundamentals and that the Saudi Arabia had an output capacity of 11.3 million barrels. The Summit laid the importance in efficient petroleum technologies for the protection of the local, regional, and global environment, and the importance of expediting the development of technologies that address climate change. The the event also discussed the core principle of respective capabilities in addressing climate change policies and measures, including the implementation of UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and Kyoto Protocol.
